html:
• anchor

    Image: © Peter Cook (Peter Cook Studio Crablab). Courtesy Serpentine.

    Peter Cook has been attached to a special site-specific pavilion commissioned by the LEGO Group on the grounds of the Serpentine Gallery that will open this summer to coincide with the official celebration of World Play Day in London. 

    His upcoming Play Pavilion design, first announced in late February by the gallery, will be intended for children and take its place alongside Marina Tabassum’s kinetic pavilion shortly after her contribution to the annual summer fete debuts June 6th.

    Described as an "immersive environment where visitors can explore the creative power of play in three dimensions," the commission places a colorful geodesic dome made from LEGO bricks next to the Serpentine South's location in Kensington Gardens. 

    Once inside its mast-like and 'mysterious' mural-lined walls, users will find their own play identities and then make their fantasies come to life while contributing to its overall appearance as a Gesamtkunstwerk (or 'total work of art'). Reveals from the interior are attained through careful punctures in the ETFE-wrapped walls. The Play Pavilion's gross footprint is just under 937 square feet. 

    In relating his ambitions for the project, Cook stated: "Play transcends survival, achievement, and common sense. It encourages, or at least permits us, to explore and idly delight in a territory between the wayward and speculative towards unashamed amusement. [The pavilion] is a piece of theatre. It’s a space for gatherings, small events, workshops and performances. In contrast to the austere monuments that populate the parks, it reminds us we should never take ourselves too seriously."

    Cook also described it as "a graphic toy." The project is the culmination of a vision put forth by the late Zaha Hadid many years ago, according to Serpentine artistic director Hans Ulrich Obrist. 

    It is the next in a series of new public design programs geared toward teenagers and championing the spirit of play and community engagement that inspired both architects at different points in their practicing lives.

    The Archigram co-founder turns 88 this year. The Play Pavilion opens to the public on Wednesday, June 11th, and will remain on view until August 10th.
